front: What is the difference between an abbreviation and an acronym?
back: An abbreviation is a shortened form of a word (e.g., 'Dr.'), while an acronym is formed from the first letters of a phrase (e.g., HTML = HyperText Markup Language).

front: Which HTML element should you use to mark up abbreviations or acronyms?

back: It semantically marks text as an abbreviation or acronym, and optionally provides a full description via the title attribute.

front: How do you display the full meaning of an abbreviation using HTML?
back: Use the title attribute in the <abbr> element. For example: <abbr title="HyperText Markup Language">HTML</abbr>.

front: How does the title attribute in <abbr> affect user experience?
back: It allows users to see a tooltip with the full form of the abbreviation when they hover over it.

front: Does the <abbr> element always change the appearance of the text?
back: No. It may be styled differently depending on the browser, but by default it often looks like normal text unless the title attribute is added.

front: Should you use <abbr> for every abbreviation on a page?
back: Not necessarily. Use it when the abbreviation might be unclear or when it benefits from additional context.

front: What is an example of using <abbr> to mark an acronym?
What visual cue might browsers add to an <abbr> with a title attribute?
back: Some browsers show a dotted underline or display small caps, along with a tooltip on hover.

front: Why should you use the <abbr> element for acronyms like HTML or CSS?
back: It provides semantic meaning, improves accessibility, and helps users understand abbreviations with tooltips.
